Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: Surveillance and Citizenship for People on Pretrial Release

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Because people in the United States are thought to be innocent until proven guilty, there has recently been much controversy over social bias in pretrial processes. In response, current restructuring practices often include bond reform, which can result in decreases in pretrial incarceration, but also usually leads to increases in other measures of surveillance, such as electronic monitoring, 24-hour curfews, or random drug tests. We know very little about how surveillance practices during the pretrial stage can impact access to political, civil, and social citizenship, although we do know that these practices are stratified by social group. This project studies how people who are released pretrial still experience methods of surveillance and why certain people are more likely to experience harsher measures of surveillance than others. By better understanding how surveillance influences an accused person's life and who is more acutely impacted by this surveillance, this project will provide insight into how the criminal legal system stratifies citizenship even before an individual is convicted of a crime. Further, findings from this project will inform governmental policy regarding the treatment of accused people who have yet to stand trial.

This project use two sources of data: ethnographic courtroom observations and in-depth interviews. The project will include six months of courtroom observations in a large city in order to understand which types of cases result which types of disposition and surveillance in the context of pre-trial release. The project will also conduct 60 in-depth, semi-structured interviews with people accused of felonies but who are on pretrial release. Data from these interviews will reveal details regarding pretrial conditions and how these conditions have influenced respondent economic and social statuses, as well as access to political rights. All data will be analyzed with MaxQDA for two cycles of coding. The first cycle will focus on open coding and the second cycle will focus on theoretical coding. Findings from the project will contribute to sociological theories regarding incarceration, surveillance and risk, and social citizenship within the context of United States democracy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examines the impact of pretrial surveillance for people who are released on bond while they await their trial in Cook County, Illinois. With support from the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant, Erin Eife has completed data collection for her project “Freed Without Freedom: Surveillance and Citizenship for People on Pretrial Release.” This data collection consists of two sources: ethnographic observations of pretrial hearings for hundreds of cases in Cook County Central Courthouse at 26th Street and California Avenue in Chicago, Illinois and 58 interviews with people currently or recently on pretrial release in Cook County.

 

The fieldnotes from Erin’s courtroom ethnography allows her to understand the factors that contribute to different pretrial surveillance outcomes for people who are accused of a felony in Cook County. For this ethnography, Erin conducted observations in Central Bond Court and observed a total of six judges in the bond court rotation. She also conducted observations in three courtrooms that deal with pretrial hearings post-bond. The court actors, including the judges and State’s Attorney, were diverse in race and gender. In order to document these observations, Erin wrote field notes with paper and pen due to the restriction on electronic materials in the courthouse. After each set of observations, Erin returned home to type up handwritten notes on her computer immediately.

 

In addition to these courtroom observations, Erin also conducted semi-structured in-depth interviews. The interviews collected for this project were used to understand the lived experiences of people on pretrial release in Cook County. Respondents varied in age (range=19-63), race (49 Black people, 5 Latinx people, and 4 white people), gender (42 men, 13 women, and 3 trans or non-binary people), and geographic location of Cook County. This population also varied in the types of surveillance that they experienced while on pretrial release, including house arrest, GPS monitoring, drug testing, no contact orders, and no driving orders. Interviews took place at a location of the respondent’s choosing, such as a coffeeshop, a community organization’s office, or one’s place of residence. This NSF grant allowed Erin to adequately compensate all respondents for their time. Interviews lasted about an hour, on average, and were captured using an audio-recorder. The NSF grant also covered costs for the transcription of audio-recordings.

 

With a theoretical grounding in literatures of both risk and surveillance, Erin’s findings illustrate how risk is racialized in pretrial hearings and how risk becomes a tool for colorblind racism during pretrial hearings. She shows the connection between this racialized risk and the factors that influence judges’ assignment of surveillance mechanisms for people accused of felonies. Erin’s findings also call into question the idea that we are all innocent until proven guilty. She shows that surveillance mechanisms operate punitively, obscuring the citizenship rights of people on pretrial release. Because people on pretrial release have not yet been adjudicated, they should be presumed innocent. Instead, surveillance mechanisms like house arrest, constant and consistent status hearings, and pretrial monitoring, lead to loss of stable employment, secure housing, and protection from unreasonable search and seizure. Thus, Erin argues that people on pretrial release experience an alternative form of citizenship wherein they lack political, civil, and social rights even before adjudication.

 

In order to disseminate her findings, Erin has submitted several manuscripts for publication. One solo-authored journal manuscript is currently under review. A solo-authored book chapter has been accepted for the American Society of Criminology Division on Corrections and Sentencing’s Handbook on Pretrial Justice. A co-authored manuscript has received a Revise & Resubmit. Erin is currently preparing other manuscripts for publication. She hopes that these manuscripts will contribute to the understanding of the ways that pretrial surveillance is harmful and thus, might influence the way pretrial justice is handled in Cook County and perhaps, the United States as a whole. Erin’s work has also contributed to the mission of the Chicago Community Bond Fund (CCBF), a community organization who both pays bond for those who cannot afford it themselves and advocates for the end of money bond and pretrial supervision. Erin has assisted CCBF with education and advocacy projects that include data from her interviews.
